canonical_explanation.text:
Biomolecules are the organic molecules that form the structural and functional basis of living organisms. They include carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, and enzymes. Carbohydrates are polyhydroxy aldehydes or ketones classified as monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, fructose, ribose), disaccharides (e.g., sucrose, maltose, lactose), oligosaccharides, and polysaccharides (e.g., starch, glycogen, cellulose, chitin). Reducing sugars (e.g., glucose, maltose) have a free anomeric carbon and can reduce Fehling's or Benedict's solution. Lipids are heterogeneous compounds including fats, oils, phospholipids, and steroids; fats are esters of glycerol with fatty acids. Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins, linked by peptide bonds formed through condensation reactions. There are 20 standard amino acids, each having an amino group, a carboxyl group, a hydrogen atom, and a variable R group attached to a central alpha-carbon.
Proteins exhibit four levels of structural organisation: primary (linear sequence of amino acids), secondary (alpha-helix or beta-pleated sheet due to hydrogen bonding), tertiary (three-dimensional folding stabilised by various bonds), and quaternary (assembly of multiple polypeptide subunits, e.g., haemoglobin). Nucleic acids — DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and RNA (ribonucleic acid) — are polymers of nucleotides. Each nucleotide consists of a nitrogenous base (purine or pyrimidine), a pentose sugar, and a phosphate group. DNA has deoxyribose sugar and bases A, T, G, C; RNA has ribose sugar and bases A, U, G, C. Enzymes are biological catalysts, mostly proteins, that accelerate biochemical reactions without being consumed. They are classified into six major classes: oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases, and ligases. Enzyme activity is explained by the lock-and-key model and the induced fit model. Factors affecting enzyme activity include temperature, pH, substrate concentration, and the presence of inhibitors (competitive and non-competitive). Cofactors (metal ions), coenzymes (organic molecules like NAD⁺, FAD), and prosthetic groups are non-protein components essential for enzyme function.
rules: Carbohydrates are classified as monosaccharides, disaccharides, oligosaccharides, and polysaccharides based on the number of sugar units.
Reducing sugars have a free anomeric carbon and reduce Fehling's solution (e.g., glucose, maltose); sucrose is a non-reducing sugar.
Amino acids are linked by peptide bonds (–CO–NH–) formed by condensation (dehydration synthesis).
Protein structure: primary (amino acid sequence), secondary (α-helix/β-sheet), tertiary (3D folding), quaternary (multiple subunits).
DNA nucleotides contain deoxyribose, phosphate, and bases A/T/G/C; RNA nucleotides contain ribose and bases A/U/G/C.
Purines (adenine, guanine) have a double-ring structure; pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine/uracil) have a single ring.
Enzymes are biological catalysts that lower activation energy and are highly specific in their action.
Enzyme classification: oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases, and ligases.
Lock-and-key model: substrate fits exactly into the active site; induced fit model: active site changes shape upon substrate binding.
Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate for the active site; non-competitive inhibitors bind at an allosteric site.
Cofactors are inorganic (metal ions like Zn²⁺, Mg²⁺); coenzymes are organic (e.g., NAD⁺, NADP⁺, FAD, coenzyme A).
The holoenzyme is the complete, catalytically active enzyme = apoenzyme (protein part) + cofactor/coenzyme.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a monosaccharide?
questions.explanation_correct: Glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) is a monosaccharide — the simplest form of carbohydrate that cannot be hydrolysed further into simpler sugars. It is a six-carbon aldose sugar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sucrose and maltose are disaccharides (composed of two monosaccharide units). Starch is a polysaccharide. Glucose is the correct answer as it is a simple monosaccharide.

questions.question_text: Sucrose is a disaccharide composed of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sucrose (table sugar) is a disaccharide formed by the condensation of one molecule of glucose and one molecule of fructose, linked by a glycosidic bond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glucose + Glucose forms maltose. Glucose + Galactose forms lactose. Sucrose is specifically composed of glucose and fructose joined by a glycosidic bond.

questions.question_text: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in:

options.text: Exoskeleton of arthropods and fungal cell walls

questions.explanation_correct: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide made of N-acetylglucosamine units. It forms the exoskeleton of arthropods (insects, crustaceans) and is also a major component of fungal cell walls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plant cell walls contain cellulose, not chitin. Animal muscles contain proteins like actin and myosin. Bacterial cell walls contain peptidoglycan. Chitin is specifically found in arthropod exoskeletons and fungal cell walls.

questions.question_text: Lipids are soluble in:

options.text: Organic solvents such as chloroform and ether

questions.explanation_correct: Lipids are hydrophobic or amphipathic molecules that are insoluble in water but readily soluble in organic (non-polar) solvents such as chloroform, ether, benzene, and acetone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lipids are not soluble in water, dilute acids, or dilute alkalis due to their predominantly non-polar nature. They dissolve in organic solvents because of like-dissolves-like principle.

questions.question_text: A fat molecule is formed by the esterification of:
questions.explanation_correct: A fat (triglyceride) is formed by the esterification of one molecule of glycerol with three fatty acid molecules. Each fatty acid links to glycerol through an ester bond with the release of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amino acids form proteins through peptide bonds. Nucleotides form nucleic acids. Glucose is a carbohydrate. Fats are specifically esters of glycerol and three fatty acids.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-reducing sugar?
questions.explanation_correct: Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar because the glycosidic bond between glucose and fructose involves both their anomeric carbons, leaving no free anomeric carbon to act as a reducing agent. It does not reduce Fehling's or Benedict's solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glucose, maltose, and lactose are all reducing sugars as they have a free anomeric carbon that can reduce cupric ions in Fehling's or Benedict's solution. Sucrose is the notable non-reducing disaccharide.

questions.question_text: Cellulose differs from starch in that cellulose:

options.text: Has β-1,4 glycosidic linkages and is a structural polysaccharide
Is a storage polysaccharide in animals

questions.explanation_correct: Cellulose is a structural polysaccharide with β-1,4 glycosidic linkages between glucose units, forming straight, rigid chains. Starch has α-1,4 and α-1,6 linkages and serves as a storage polysaccharide in plants. Most organisms cannot digest cellulose due to the β-linkages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both cellulose and starch are composed of glucose, not fructose. Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals. Cellulose is insoluble in water. The key difference lies in the type of glycosidic linkage (β vs α).

questions.question_text: An amino acid at neutral pH exists as a:
questions.explanation_correct: At neutral pH, an amino acid exists as a zwitterion (dipolar ion), with the amino group protonated (–NH₃⁺) and the carboxyl group deprotonated (–COO⁻). This gives the molecule both positive and negative charges simultaneously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amino acids are not exclusively cations or anions at neutral pH. They are not uncharged either. The zwitterionic form is characteristic of amino acids at their isoelectric point.

questions.question_text: Saturated fatty acids differ from unsaturated fatty acids in that saturated fatty acids:

options.text: Have one or more double bonds between carbon atoms
Have no double bonds and are generally solid at room temperature
Are always liquid at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Saturated fatty acids have no carbon-carbon double bonds in their hydrocarbon chain. Their straight chains pack tightly, making them generally solid at room temperature (e.g., palmitic acid, stearic acid found in animal fats like butter and ghee).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unsaturated fatty acids are the ones with double bonds and are generally liquid at room temperature (oils). Saturated fatty acids are found in both animals and plants. The absence of double bonds makes saturated fats solid.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about polysaccharides:
(i) Glycogen is a storage polysaccharide found in animals.
(ii) Cellulose has α-1,4 glycosidic bonds.
(iii) Starch consists of amylose and amylopectin.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (i) is correct — glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals (stored in liver and muscles). Statement (ii) is incorrect — cellulose has β-1,4 glycosidic bonds, not α-1,4. Statement (iii) is correct — starch consists of amylose (unbranched, α-1,4 linkages) and amylopectin (branched, α-1,4 and α-1,6 linkages).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key error is in statement (ii): cellulose has β-1,4 linkages, which make it structurally different from starch. Only statements (i) and (iii) are factually correct.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Phospholipids are amphipathic molecules.
Reason (R): They have a hydrophilic phosphate head and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Phospholipids are amphipathic because they possess both a hydrophilic (water-loving) phosphate head group and two hydrophobic (water-fearing) fatty acid tails. This dual nature is what makes them amphipathic and ideal for forming biological membranes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The amphipathic nature of phospholipids is indeed due to having both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. The reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following correctly matches the disaccharide with its constituent monosaccharides?
(i) Maltose — Glucose + Glucose
(ii) Lactose — Glucose + Galactose
(iii) Sucrose — Glucose + Galactose
questions.explanation_correct: Maltose = Glucose + Glucose (correct). Lactose = Glucose + Galactose (correct). Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose (not Galactose), so statement (iii) is wrong. Only (i) and (ii) are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iii) is incorrect because sucrose is composed of glucose and fructose, not glucose and galactose. The other two matchings are correct.

questions.question_text: The general formula of carbohydrates is:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates have the general empirical formula Cₙ(H₂O)ₙ, which is why they are called 'hydrates of carbon'. For example, glucose is C₆H₁₂O₆ or C₆(H₂O)₆.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other formulas do not correctly represent the general composition of carbohydrates. The name 'carbohydrate' itself reflects the formula Cₙ(H₂O)ₙ — carbon with water.

questions.question_text: Proteins are polymers of:
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are polymers of amino acids linked together by peptide bonds. There are 20 standard amino acids that combine in various sequences and lengths to form the enormous diversity of proteins in living organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nucleotides form nucleic acids (DNA, RNA). Fatty acids are components of lipids. Monosaccharides form polysaccharides. Proteins are specifically made up of amino acids.

questions.question_text: The bond that links two amino acids in a protein is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A peptide bond (–CO–NH–) is formed between the carboxyl group (–COOH) of one amino acid and the amino group (–NH₂) of another, with the release of a water molecule (condensation/dehydration synthesis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glycosidic bonds link monosaccharides. Ester bonds link glycerol to fatty acids. Hydrogen bonds stabilise secondary protein structure but are not the primary covalent links between amino acids. Peptide bonds are the specific covalent bonds in proteins.

questions.question_text: The primary structure of a protein refers to:

options.text: The three-dimensional folding of the polypeptide
The linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain
The assembly of multiple polypeptide subunits

questions.explanation_correct: The primary structure of a protein is the linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain, determined by the gene encoding it. It is the most basic level of protein organisation and dictates all higher levels of structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three-dimensional folding is the tertiary structure. Assembly of subunits is quaternary structure. Alpha-helix and beta-sheet are secondary structures. Primary structure is the amino acid sequence itself.

questions.question_text: DNA differs from RNA in that DNA contains:
questions.explanation_correct: DNA contains deoxyribose sugar (lacking an –OH group at the 2' carbon) and the base thymine (T). RNA contains ribose sugar and uracil (U) in place of thymine. Both DNA and RNA share adenine, guanine, and cytosine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RNA has ribose sugar and uracil. DNA specifically has deoxyribose and thymine. The combination of deoxyribose with uracil or ribose with thymine does not occur in standard nucleic acids.

questions.question_text: Purines found in nucleic acids are:
questions.explanation_correct: Purines are double-ringed nitrogenous bases. Adenine (A) and guanine (G) are the two purines found in nucleic acids. Pyrimidines (single-ringed) include cytosine (C), thymine (T, in DNA), and uracil (U, in RNA).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cytosine, thymine, and uracil are pyrimidines, not purines. The two purines in nucleic acids are adenine and guanine, both having a double-ring structure.

questions.question_text: Haemoglobin is an example of a protein with quaternary structure because it:

options.text: Is a linear chain of amino acids
Is composed of four polypeptide subunits (2α and 2β)
Contains only one polypeptide chain folded into a 3D shape

questions.explanation_correct: Haemoglobin has a quaternary structure because it consists of four polypeptide subunits — two alpha (α) chains and two beta (β) chains — each associated with a haem group containing iron. This multi-subunit assembly defines quaternary structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A linear amino acid chain is the primary structure. Alpha-helix alone is secondary structure. A single folded polypeptide is tertiary structure. Quaternary structure specifically involves the assembly of multiple polypeptide subunits.

questions.question_text: The secondary structure of a protein is stabilised by:

options.text: Hydrogen bonds between the backbone –CO and –NH groups

questions.explanation_correct: The secondary structure (alpha-helix and beta-pleated sheet) is stabilised by hydrogen bonds formed between the C=O group of one amino acid and the N–H group of another amino acid in the polypeptide backbone (not the side chains).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peptide bonds hold amino acids together in the primary structure. Disulphide bonds and ionic bonds between R groups contribute to tertiary structure. Secondary structure is specifically stabilised by backbone hydrogen bonds.

questions.question_text: A nucleoside differs from a nucleotide in that a nucleotide additionally contains:
questions.explanation_correct: A nucleoside consists of a nitrogenous base + a pentose sugar. A nucleotide is a nucleoside + a phosphate group. The phosphate group is what distinguishes a nucleotide from a nucleoside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both nucleosides and nucleotides contain a nitrogenous base and a pentose sugar. A nucleotide is formed when a phosphate group is added to a nucleoside through a phosphoester bond.

questions.question_text: Collagen is a protein that has:

options.text: A quaternary structure with four globular subunits

questions.explanation_correct: Collagen is a fibrous protein with a unique triple-helical structure, where three polypeptide chains are wound around each other. It is the most abundant protein in the animal body, found in connective tissues, bones, and cartilage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collagen has more than just primary structure. It does not have a typical beta-sheet structure. While it has multiple chains, it is a fibrous protein with a triple helix, not four globular subunits.

questions.question_text:
Match the following levels of protein structure with their characteristics:
(i) Primary — (a) Alpha-helix and beta-pleated sheet
(ii) Secondary — (b) Linear sequence of amino acids
(iii) Tertiary — (c) Three-dimensional folding of a single polypeptide
Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Primary structure is the linear sequence of amino acids (b). Secondary structure involves regular folding patterns like alpha-helix and beta-pleated sheet (a). Tertiary structure is the three-dimensional folding of the entire polypeptide (c).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching follows the standard hierarchy: primary = amino acid sequence, secondary = local folding patterns (helix/sheet), tertiary = overall 3D shape of the polypeptide chain.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): RNA is usually single-stranded.
Reason (R): RNA contains uracil instead of thymine.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. RNA is usually single-stranded, and RNA does contain uracil instead of thymine. However, the presence of uracil is not the reason for RNA being single-stranded. RNA is single-stranded because it does not typically form stable complementary base pairing with another strand over its entire length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While both facts are true, they are not causally related. The single-stranded nature of RNA is not a consequence of having uracil. It is due to RNA being synthesised as a single chain and not typically having a complementary partner strand.

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of RNA carries amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Transfer RNA (tRNA) carries specific amino acids to the ribosome and has an anticodon that pairs with the codon on mRNA. It acts as an adaptor molecule, translating the nucleotide sequence into an amino acid sequence during translation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: mRNA carries the genetic message from DNA to the ribosome. rRNA is a structural and catalytic component of the ribosome. snRNA is involved in RNA splicing. Only tRNA transports amino acids to the ribosome.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following about nucleic acids:
(i) Adenine pairs with thymine in DNA through two hydrogen bonds.
(ii) Guanine pairs with cytosine through three hydrogen bonds.
(iii) DNA is typically double-stranded while RNA is usually single-stranded.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: All three statements are correct. A–T base pairs are held by 2 hydrogen bonds. G–C base pairs are held by 3 hydrogen bonds (making them stronger). DNA is typically double-stranded and RNA is usually single-stranded.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three statements accurately describe nucleic acid properties. A–T pairing involves 2 H-bonds, G–C pairing involves 3 H-bonds, and the strandedness of DNA vs RNA is correctly stated.

questions.question_text: Denaturation of a protein involves:

options.text: Disruption of secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures without breaking peptide bonds
Addition of new amino acids to the chain

questions.explanation_correct: Denaturation involves the disruption of the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of a protein due to heat, pH changes, or chemicals. The primary structure (peptide bonds) remains intact, but the protein loses its biological activity and native conformation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peptide bonds are not broken during denaturation — that would be hydrolysis. The primary structure is preserved. No new amino acids are added. Denaturation specifically affects the higher-order structures.

questions.question_text: Enzymes are chemically:
questions.explanation_correct: Almost all enzymes are proteins. However, some RNA molecules (ribozymes) also possess catalytic activity. Enzymes function as biological catalysts, speeding up biochemical reactions by lowering the activation energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzymes are not carbohydrates or lipids. While some nucleic acids (ribozymes) have catalytic activity, the vast majority of enzymes are proteins. The correct answer acknowledges both protein enzymes and the exception of RNA-based enzymes.

questions.question_text: The active site of an enzyme is the region where:

options.text: The product is stored after the reaction
The substrate binds and the catalytic reaction occurs

questions.explanation_correct: The active site is a small, three-dimensional pocket or cleft on the enzyme surface where the substrate binds and undergoes a chemical reaction. It is formed by specific amino acid residues and determines the enzyme's specificity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Products are released from the active site, not stored there. Enzymes are synthesised on ribosomes. Cofactors may or may not be at the active site. The active site is specifically the substrate-binding and catalytic region.

questions.question_text: Enzymes that catalyse the transfer of a functional group from one molecule to another are classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Transferases catalyse the transfer of specific functional groups (such as amino, methyl, acyl, or phosphoryl groups) from one substrate (donor) to another (acceptor). Examples include transaminases and kinases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxidoreductases catalyse oxidation-reduction reactions. Hydrolases catalyse hydrolysis reactions. Ligases catalyse the joining of two molecules. Transferases specifically transfer functional groups between molecules.

questions.question_text: The holoenzyme consists of:
questions.explanation_correct: A holoenzyme is the complete, catalytically active form of an enzyme, composed of the apoenzyme (protein part) along with its cofactor (inorganic metal ion) or coenzyme (organic molecule). The apoenzyme alone is inactive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The protein part alone is the apoenzyme, which is inactive. The cofactor alone is not an enzyme. The holoenzyme is specifically the combination of apoenzyme and its non-protein component (cofactor/coenzyme).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a coenzyme?
questions.explanation_correct: NAD⁺ is a coenzyme — an organic, non-protein molecule that assists enzymes in catalytic reactions. It acts as an electron carrier in metabolic reactions. Zinc, iron, and magnesium are inorganic cofactors (metal ions), not coenzymes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zn²⁺, Fe²⁺, and Mg²⁺ are inorganic cofactors (metal ions), not coenzymes. Coenzymes are organic molecules, often derived from vitamins. NAD⁺ is derived from niacin (vitamin B₃) and is a classic example of a coenzyme.

questions.question_text: In competitive inhibition of an enzyme:

options.text: The inhibitor binds to the allosteric site
The inhibitor closely resembles the substrate and competes for the active site
The inhibitor permanently destroys the enzyme
The inhibitor increases the rate of reaction

questions.explanation_correct: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor molecule has a structure similar to the substrate and competes with it for binding to the active site. The inhibition can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Binding to the allosteric site is non-competitive inhibition. Competitive inhibitors do not permanently destroy the enzyme. They do not increase the reaction rate — they decrease it by blocking substrate access to the active site.

questions.question_text: According to the induced fit model of enzyme action:

options.text: The active site is rigid and the substrate fits perfectly like a key in a lock
The active site changes its shape slightly to accommodate the substrate upon binding
The enzyme is destroyed after one catalytic cycle
The product remains permanently attached to the enzyme

questions.explanation_correct: In the induced fit model (proposed by Koshland), the active site of the enzyme is not a rigid structure. It changes shape slightly upon substrate binding to achieve a more complementary fit, enhancing catalysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rigid active site concept is the lock-and-key model. Enzymes are not destroyed after catalysis — they are reusable. Products are released after the reaction. The induced fit model emphasises flexibility of the active site.

questions.question_text: The optimum temperature for most human enzymes is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Most human enzymes function optimally at about 37°C (normal body temperature). At temperatures below this, the reaction rate decreases. At temperatures significantly above this, the enzyme denatures and loses its catalytic activity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 0°C, enzyme activity is very low. 25°C is below optimum for human enzymes. At 60°C, most human enzymes would denature. The optimum temperature closely corresponds to normal human body temperature of 37°C.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct classification for an enzyme that catalyses the breakdown of a substrate by adding water?
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrolases catalyse hydrolysis reactions — the breaking of bonds by the addition of water. Examples include lipases (which hydrolyse lipids), proteases (proteins), and amylases (starch).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lyases catalyse removal of groups without hydrolysis. Isomerases catalyse structural rearrangements. Ligases join two molecules using ATP. Hydrolases specifically break bonds using water.

questions.question_text: Non-competitive inhibition of an enzyme can be identified by the fact that:

options.text: It can be reversed by increasing substrate concentration
The inhibitor binds at a site other than the active site and cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration
The inhibitor is structurally similar to the substrate
The Km value of the enzyme increases

questions.explanation_correct: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds at an allosteric site (different from the active site), changing the shape of the enzyme. This inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration, as the inhibitor does not compete with the substrate for the active site.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Competitive inhibition can be reversed by increasing substrate. Structural similarity to substrate is a feature of competitive inhibitors. In non-competitive inhibition, Km remains unchanged but Vmax decreases.

questions.question_text:
Match the following enzyme classes with their functions:
(i) Oxidoreductases — (a) Transfer of functional groups
(ii) Transferases — (b) Joining of two molecules using ATP
(iii) Ligases — (c) Oxidation-reduction reactions
Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Oxidoreductases catalyse oxidation-reduction reactions (c). Transferases transfer functional groups from one molecule to another (a). Ligases join two molecules using energy from ATP hydrolysis (b).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each enzyme class has a specific function: oxidoreductases handle redox reactions, transferases transfer groups, and ligases join molecules with ATP. The correct matching is (i)-(c), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(b).

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Enzymes are highly specific in their action.
Reason (R): The active site of an enzyme is complementary in shape and charge to its specific substrate.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Enzymes are indeed highly specific, typically catalysing only one type of reaction with a specific substrate. This specificity arises because the active site is complementary in shape, charge, and chemical properties to its particular substrate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzyme specificity is well established and is directly explained by the complementary nature of the active site. The reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements:
(i) Enzymes lower the activation energy of a reaction.
(ii) Enzymes alter the equilibrium of a reaction.
(iii) Enzymes are consumed in the reaction they catalyse.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Only statement (i) is correct — enzymes lower the activation energy, thereby increasing the rate of the reaction. Statement (ii) is incorrect — enzymes do not alter the equilibrium of a reaction; they only speed up the attainment of equilibrium. Statement (iii) is incorrect — enzymes are not consumed and are regenerated after each catalytic cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzymes do not change the equilibrium position or the free energy change of a reaction. They are biological catalysts that are reusable and are not consumed. The only correct statement is that they lower the activation energy.

questions.question_text: At very high substrate concentrations, the rate of an enzyme-catalysed reaction:

options.text: Reaches a maximum velocity (Vmax) and plateaus

questions.explanation_correct: At very high substrate concentrations, all enzyme molecules are saturated (every active site is occupied). The reaction rate reaches a maximum velocity (Vmax) and cannot increase further, regardless of additional substrate — this results in a plateau in the velocity vs substrate concentration graph.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rate does not increase indefinitely because enzyme concentration is limited. It does not decrease or become zero at high substrate levels. The plateau at Vmax is a fundamental characteristic of enzyme kinetics.

questions.question_text: Glycogen is similar to amylopectin in that both:

options.text: Are storage polysaccharides with α-1,4 and α-1,6 glycosidic bonds
Are structural polysaccharides found in cell walls

questions.explanation_correct: Both glycogen and amylopectin are branched storage polysaccharides with α-1,4 glycosidic bonds in the main chain and α-1,6 glycosidic bonds at branch points. Glycogen is more extensively branched than amylopectin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neither is a structural polysaccharide (cellulose and chitin are structural). Both are composed of glucose, not fructose. β-1,4 linkages are found in cellulose. Their similarity lies in being branched storage polysaccharides with α-linkages.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of lipids in biological systems?
questions.explanation_correct: Catalysis of biochemical reactions is the function of enzymes (which are mostly proteins), not lipids. Lipids serve as energy reserves, form cell membranes (phospholipids), and are precursors to hormones (cholesterol → steroid hormones).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy storage (fats), membrane structure (phospholipids), and hormone synthesis (steroids) are all well-known functions of lipids. Catalysis is performed by enzymes, not lipids.

questions.question_text: The sugar present in RNA is:
questions.explanation_correct: RNA (ribonucleic acid) contains ribose sugar in its nucleotides. Ribose has an –OH group at the 2' carbon, unlike deoxyribose (found in DNA) which lacks this –OH group at the 2' position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deoxyribose is found in DNA. Glucose and fructose are monosaccharides involved in carbohydrate metabolism, not nucleic acid structure. RNA specifically contains ribose sugar.

questions.question_text: Which of the following bonds stabilises the tertiary structure of a protein?

options.text: Hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, hydrophobic interactions, and disulphide bonds

questions.explanation_correct: The tertiary structure of a protein is stabilised by various interactions between R groups (side chains) of amino acids: hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds (salt bridges), hydrophobic interactions, van der Waals forces, and covalent disulphide bonds between cysteine residues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peptide bonds determine primary structure. Glycosidic bonds link sugars. Phosphodiester bonds link nucleotides. Tertiary structure involves multiple types of interactions between amino acid side chains.

questions.question_text: Enzymes that catalyse the rearrangement of atoms within a molecule (isomer formation) are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Isomerases catalyse the structural rearrangement within a single molecule, converting it from one isomeric form to another. For example, phosphoglucoisomerase converts glucose-6-phosphate to fructose-6-phosphate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrolases break bonds using water. Lyases remove groups without hydrolysis. Transferases transfer groups between molecules. Isomerases specifically catalyse intramolecular rearrangements.

questions.question_text: A prosthetic group differs from a coenzyme in that a prosthetic group:

options.text: Is always an inorganic metal ion
Is loosely attached to the enzyme and dissociates easily
Is tightly and permanently bound to the apoenzyme
Is not required for enzyme activity

questions.explanation_correct: A prosthetic group is an organic molecule that is tightly and permanently bound to the apoenzyme (e.g., haem in haemoglobin, FAD in succinate dehydrogenase). In contrast, coenzymes bind loosely and can dissociate from the enzyme after the reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Prosthetic groups are organic, not inorganic metal ions (those are cofactors). Loose attachment describes coenzymes. Prosthetic groups are essential for enzyme activity. Their tight binding distinguishes them from coenzymes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an amino acid?
questions.explanation_correct: Glycine is the simplest amino acid, with a hydrogen atom as its R group. It is the only amino acid that is not optically active (achiral). Adenine is a nitrogenous base, ribose is a sugar, and palmitic acid is a fatty acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adenine is a purine base found in nucleic acids. Ribose is a pentose sugar. Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid. Glycine is a standard amino acid with the formula NH₂–CH₂–COOH.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the lock-and-key model of enzyme action?

options.text: The enzyme changes its shape to fit the substrate
The substrate is rigid and the enzyme is flexible
The active site has a fixed shape that is exactly complementary to the substrate
Multiple substrates can fit into the same active site simultaneously

questions.explanation_correct: The lock-and-key model (proposed by Emil Fischer) states that the active site of an enzyme has a fixed, rigid shape that is exactly complementary to its specific substrate, just as a lock is complementary to its specific key.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzyme changing shape to fit the substrate describes the induced fit model. The lock-and-key model emphasises rigidity and pre-existing complementarity. Each active site typically binds one specific substrate at a time.

questions.question_text: The effect of pH on enzyme activity is best described as:

options.text: Enzyme activity increases continuously as pH increases
Each enzyme has an optimum pH at which activity is maximum; activity decreases on either side of this optimum
pH has no effect on enzyme activity
All enzymes work best at pH 7 (neutral)

questions.explanation_correct: Each enzyme has a specific optimum pH at which its activity is highest. Deviations from this optimum (either more acidic or more alkaline) reduce enzyme activity due to changes in the ionisation state of amino acids in the active site. For example, pepsin works best at pH 2, while trypsin works best at pH 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzyme activity does not increase continuously with pH. pH significantly affects enzyme activity. Not all enzymes have an optimum at pH 7 — pepsin works best at pH 2, while alkaline phosphatase works best at alkaline pH.
